results.title: L'aigle a Deux Tetes = the Two-Headed Eagle
results.creator_credit: Jean Cocteau, Alexandre Mnouchkine and Georges Dancigers
results.brief_description:
In a small mid-European kingdom in the 19th century, a young anarchist who happens to be the perfect look-alike of the dead king, breaks into the palace in order to kill the queen, but falls in love with her. Pauline Kael has characterized Jean Cocteau’s ‘The Two-Headed Eagle’ as an inversion of Cocteau’s ‘Beauty and the Beast’. On surface, this is true: In ‘Beauty’, the heroine awakens the handsome, good man lurking within the beast, while in ‘Eagle’ it is the woman who is aroused from her spell by the hero. Although Cocteau’s cinematic sense is too great to make the film look stagey, the screenplay smacks too much of the theatre. It is the most minor of his own directed films. ‘Il Mistero di Oberwald’ (The Mystery of Oberwald) directed by Michelangelo Antonioni was based on ‘The Two Headed Eagle’.

Credits: Producer, Georges Dancigers, Alexandre Mnouchkine ; director, Jean Cocteau ; writer, Jean Cocteau ; photography, Christian Matras ; music, Georges Auric ; art direction, Christian Berard, Georges Wakhevitch ; stills photographer, Raymond Voin
Cast: Edwige Feuillere, Jean Marais, Jean Debucourt, Jacques Varennes, Silvia Monfort, Yvonne de Bray.

results.title: Buffet Froid = Cold Cuts
results.creator_credit: Bertrand Blier and WDR La Sept Cinema
results.brief_description:
Alphonse Tram discovers his penknife planted in the belly of a moribund accountant lying in a subway corridor. He tries to engage in a conversation with the moribund who rebuffs him. Lost and angry, Alphonse goes back home, in the modern tower where he lives with his wife. She introduces him to their new neighbour, a police inspector. Later Alphonse’s wife is found murdered and her hapless murderer almost immediately confesses to Alphonse, but neither the husband, nor the police inspector seem to be shocked. The three sit down to enjoy a friendly drink when a man arrives and accuses Alphonse of the subway murder. ‘Buffet Froid’ is a wonderfully absurd black comedy that cunningly reverses the conventions of the crime thriller to comment on the alienating and dehumanizing effects of contemporary urban life.

Credits: Producer, Alain Sarde ; director, Bertrand Blier ; writer, Bertrand Blier ; photography, Jean Penzer ; music, Philippe Sarde, Johannes Brahms ; art direction, Theobald Meurisse.
Cast: Gerard Depardieu, Bernard Blier, Jean Carmet, Genevieve Page, Michel Serrault, Carole Bouquet, Jean Rougerie, Bernard Crombey, Denise Gence, Jean Benguigui, Liliane Rovere.

results.title: Les Orgueilleux = the Proud Ones
results.brief_description:
Well-bred Nelly and down-and-out doctor Georges cross paths in Vera Cruz, Mexico, in this absorbing tale of love, religion, and the effects of a deadly plague on the impoverished populace.

Credits: Producer, Louis Wipf ; director, Yves Allegret ; writers, Yves Allegret, Jean Aurenche, Jean Clouzot ; photography, Alex Phillips ; music, Paul Misraki ; sound, William-Robert Sivel ; stills photographer, Raymond Voinquel.
Cast: Michele Morgan, Gerard Philipe, Michele Cordoue, Carlos Lopez, Victor, Manuel Mendoza.

results.title: Teresa
results.creator_credit: Gerard Vergez and Francois de Lannurien
results.brief_description:
Teresa, a middle aged women in financial strife has to take in a tenant. A young woman soon moves in. Lorenzo, Teresa’s estranged lover soon becomes infatuated by the young tenant. Awards: Grand Prix Feminin du Cinema, 1970.

Credits: Producer, Francois de Lannurien ; director, Gerard Vergez ; writers, Gerard Vergez, Michel Arnaud ; photography, Guy Fellous ; music, Vladimir Cosma.
Cast: Suzanne Flon, Robert Rimbaud, Anne Doat, Jeanne Allard.

results.title: Poil de Carotte = Red Head
results.brief_description:
In rural France, ‘Poil de Carotte’, an undernourished and unloved young boy, is badly treated by is ageing mother but his often absent father is unaware of all this. Everything comes to a head when the boy attempts suicide. The film opens a stunning establishing shot, nearly two minutes long and containing eleven distinct movements. ‘Poil de Carotte’ was filmed by Julien Duvivier in 1926 (silent). It was re-made by Paul Mesnier (1952) and Henri Graziani (1973).

Credits: Director, Julien Duvivier ; writers, Julien Duvivier, Jules Renard ; photography, Armand Thirard, Emile Monniot ; music, Alexandre Tansman ; art direction, Lucien Aguettant, Lucien Carre.
Cast: Harry Baur, Robert Lynen, Louis Gauthier, Catherine Fontenay.

results.title: History brought to life. King of kings
results.creator_credit: Cecil B. DeMille, Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences and Pathé Frères
results.brief_description: History brought to life (9 mins) hosted by Cecil B. DeMille unfolds the glory of early Hollywood and its massive industry at work, providing a dazzling array of stars and historic milestone film events. “King of kings” (1927-112 mins) acknowledged as the definitive film of Jesus, presents the story of Christ as a moving portrait seen through the eyes of Mary Magdalene.

results.title: Thomas L'imposteur = Thomas the Imposter
results.brief_description:
Thomas is a 16 year old who poses as the nephew of a general to help a princess get to Paris during World War I. She helps wounded soldiers by taking them back to her castle for medical care.

Credits: Producer, Eugene Lepicier ; director, Georges Franju ; writers, Jean Cocteau, Michel Worms, Georges Franju, Raphael Cluzel ; photography, Marcel Fradetal ; music, Georges Auric.
Cast: Emmanuelle Riva, Fabrice Rouleau, Rosy Varte, Bernard Lavalette, Jean-Roger Caussimon, Michel Vitold, Gabrielle Dorziat, Jean Marais.

results.title: Celine et Julie Vont En Bateau = Celine and Julie Go Boating
results.brief_description:
This is an adventure in narrative fiction involving two pairs of heroines and an old dark house in a fairytale that spins around both the protagonists and the audience. One pair (Ogier and Pisier) forms a phantom triangle with a widower in the house of fiction that Berto and Labourier enter. What ensues is a strange, hieratic tragedy borrowed from Henry James. Rivette’s film is in turn magical, joyous and unsettling and, at times, all three at once, a journey through the movie experience itself, an exhilarating display of parodies and genre pastiches forming what amounts to a meditation on the art of illusion. The four female lead actresses collaborated to the writing of the script. Jacques Rivette won the Special Prize of the Jury at the Locarno International Film Festival (1974). Further viewing: ‘Daisies’ (1966) directed by Vera Chytilova [2081701, VHS], from which Rivette took inspiration for ‘Celine and Julie’. Also available on VHS.

Credits: Producer, Barbet Schroeder ; director: Jacques Rivette ; writer, Eduardo de Gregorio ; photography, Jacques Renard ; music, Jean-Marie Senia ; editor, Nicole Lubtchansky.
Cast: Juliet Berto, Dominique Labourier, Bulle Ogier, Marie-France Pisier, Barbet Schroeder.

results.title: Germinal
results.brief_description:
Etienne is a young man who seeks work in the coal mines of the North of France. After experiencing the harsh working conditions of the mine, he becomes a labor activist and tries to organize a strike to improve wages and conditions. Etienne is also tormented by the mine owner, whose promiscuous wife steps out on him at will. Etienne falls in love with the daughter of a fellow miner. Her loyalty to her father and the fear he might lose his job makes her initially unresponsive to Etienne’s romantic advances.

Credits: Producer, Eugene Tuchere ; director, Yves Allegret ; writer, Charles Spaak ; photography, Jean Bourgoin ; music, Michel Magne ; art direction, Lucien Aguettand.
Cast: Jean Sorel, Berthe Grandval, Lea Padovani, Claude Brasseur, Bernard Blier.

results.title: Jenny
results.brief_description:
Jenny, the manager of a nightclub of dubious reputation, gets involved with Lucien, a member of a gang of criminals. Benoit, the crooked owner of the club, employs a hunchback accomplice to help put an end to their affair. Meanwhile, Jenny’s daughter falls in love with Lucien and becomes her mother’s rival. ‘Jenny’ is Marcel Carne’s first film as director and the first of seven collaborations with screenwriter Jacques Prevert. Reference: Bloomsbury Foreign Film Guide.

Credits: Director, Marcel Carne ; writers, Jacques Prevert, Pierre Rocher, Jacques Constant ; photography, Jean Stelli ; music, Joseph Kosma, Lionel Cazaux ; art direction, Jean d’Eaubonne.
Cast: Francoise Rosay, Albert Prejean, Charles Vanel, Lisette Lanvin, Jean-Louis Barrault, Robert Le Vigan, Roland Toutain, Sylvia Bataille, Margo Lion, Rene Genin.
